member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.TypeFactory
member.summary: Provides support for combining mixins and target classes into concrete, "mixed", instantiable types.

remarks.para: When a target class should be combined with mixins, the target class (and sometimes also the mixin types) cannot be instantiated as is. Instead, a concrete type has to be created which incorporates the necessary delegation code. While the type generation is actually performed by another class, the provides the public API to be used when retrieving a generated type.
The should only be used if objects are required. If the combined type should be instantiated, the class should be used instead.
The class uses the mixin configuration active for the thread on which it is called.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.TypeFactory.GetConcreteType(System.Type)
member.summary: Retrieves a concrete, instantiable, mixed type for the given , or itself if no mixin configuration exists for the type on the current thread.
member.param: Base type for which a mixed type should be retrieved or a concrete mixed type.
member.returns: A concrete, instantiable, mixed type for the given .

exception.para: The current mixin configuration for the contains severe configuration problems that make generation of a target class definition object impossible.
- or -
The current mixin configuration for the violates at least one validation rule, which makes code generation impossible.

remarks.para: The type returned by this method is guaranteed to be derived from , but will usually not be the same as . It manages integration of the mixins with the given .

Note that the factory will not create derived types for types not currently having a mixin configuration. This means that types returned by the factory can not always be treated as derived types. See on how to force generation of a derived type.

The returned type provides the same constructors as does and can thus be instantiated, e.g. via . When this happens, all the mixins associated with the generated type are also instantiated and configured to be used with the target instance. If you need to supply pre-created mixin instances for an object, use a MixedObjectInstantiationScope. See for a simpler way to immediately create instances of mixed types.
If is already a generated type, this method will not subclass it again.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.TypeFactory.GetConcreteType(System.Type,Remotion.Mixins.GenerationPolicy)
member.summary: Retrieves a concrete, instantiable, mixed type for the given .
member.param: Base type for which a mixed type should be retrieved or a concrete mixed type.
Defines whether to force generation of a type even if no mixin configuration is currently available for the given type.
member.returns: A concrete, instantiable, mixed type for the given , or the type itself; depending on the and the active configuration.

exception.para: The current mixin configuration for the contains severe configuration problems that make generation of a target class definition object impossible.
- or -
The current mixin configuration for the violates at least one validation rule, which makes code generation impossible.

remarks.para: The type returned by this method is guaranteed to be derived from , but will usually not be the same as . It manages integration of the mixins with the given .

Note that the factory can create empty mixin configurations for types not currently having a mixin configuration, depending on the . With , types returned by the factory can always be treated as derived types.

The returned type provides the same constructors as does and can thus be instantiated, e.g. via . When this happens, all the mixins associated with the generated type are also instantiated and configured to be used with the target instance. If you need to supply pre-created mixin instances for an object, use a MixedObjectInstantiationScope. See for a simpler way to immediately create instances of mixed types.
If is already a generated type, this method will only subclass it again when is specified.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.TypeFactory.InitializeUnconstructedInstance(System.Object)
member.summary: Initializes a mixin target instance which was created without its constructor having been called.
member.param: The mixin target to initialize.
member.remarks: This method is useful when a mixin target instance is created via .

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoresMixinAttribute
member.summary: Defines that a specific mixin is not applied to a class, even when it is explicitly or implicitly configured for that class via the declarative configuration attributes , , and .

remarks.para: Use this attribute to exclude a mixin that is configured to be applied to a base class. This attribute is not inherited, so the mixin exclusion will only work for the exact mixin to which the attribute is applied.

Note that when a generic type definition (e.g. C<>) excludes a mixin, a corresponding closed generic class (C<int>) can still inherit the mixin from its base class. This is by design due to the rule that a closed generic type inherits mixins from both its base class and its generic type definition.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoresMixinAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the mixin to be ignored by this class.
member.param: The mixin to be ignored in declarative configuration. Subclasses of this class will not inherit the mixin either.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoresMixinAttribute.MixinToIgnore
member.summary: Gets the mixin to be ignored by this class.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.BindToTargetTypeAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a generic parameter of a mixin should be bound to the mixin's target type (unless the generic parameter type is explicitly specified when the mixin is configured).

remarks.para: Apply this attribute to a generic parameter of a generic mixin when the mixin engine should be able to automatically close the mixin type. Without the attribute, an exception will be thrown.
remarks.note: When a type parameter is reused for the generic parameter of the or base classes, the type parameter must satisfy several constraints. See and for more information.

member.name: T:Remotion.Context.SafeContext
member.summary: Superior alternative to [ThreadStatic] (see ) for making member variables thread safe, which also works with ASP.NET threads.

member.name: M:Remotion.Context.SafeContext.GetDefaultInstance
member.summary: Gets or creates the default instance to be used when the is initialized.
member.returns: The default storage instance for this .

remarks.para: This method can be overridden by a mixin in order to change the default . While this method is executed, a temporary default -based storage provider is set active. Therefore, code executed from within can safely access without causing a stack overflow.

However, the fact that it is temporary means that the data written into the context will not be available after has been initialized (unless the new instance is also based on the ). This also means that it is not possible to imperatively prepare a certain mixin configuration before the is initialized; only the mixins present in the default mixin configuration will be considered for overriding this method.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.IActionInvoker
member.summary: This interface allows invokers with fixed arguments to be returned without references to their generic argument types.

remarks.p: Note that casting a to an interface is a boxing operation, thus creating an object on the heap and garbage collecting it later. For very performance-critical scenarios, it be better to avoid this and accept the references to the invoker's generic argument types.

It is recommended to wrap this interface within a , because returning an interface could lead to ambigous castings if the final call to is missing, while using structs will usually lead to a compile-time error as expected.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.UsesAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a class integrates a mixin to implement some part of its functionality or public interface.

remarks.para: This attribute is effective for the declarative mixin configuration, which is in effect by default when an application is started.

Although the attribute itself is not inherited, its semantics in mixin configuration are: If a base class is configured to be mixed with a mixin type M by means of the , this configuration setting is inherited by each of its (direct and indirect) subclasses. The subclasses will therefore also be mixed with the same mixin type M unless a second mixin M2 derived from M is applied to the subclass, thus overriding the inherited configuration. If M is configured for both base class and subclass, the base class configuration is ignored.
This attribute can be applied to the same target class multiple times if a class depends on multiple mixins, but it should not be used to apply the same mixin multiple times to the same target class.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.MixinRelationshipAttribute
member.summary: Acts as a common base class for attributes used in declaratively specifying the mixin configuration by expressing the relationship between a mixin and its target class, eg. , ,

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.MixinRelationshipAttribute.AdditionalDependencies
member.summary: Gets or sets additional explicit base call dependencies for the applied mixin type. This can be used to establish an ordering when combining unrelated mixins on a class which override the same methods.
member.value: The additional dependencies of the mixin. The validity of the dependency types is not checked until the configuration is built.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.MixinRelationshipAttribute.SuppressedMixins
member.summary: Gets or sets the mixins suppressed by the applied mixin.
member.value: The mixins suppressed by the applied mixins.
member.remarks: Use this attribute to actively remove a mixin from the attribute's target type. The list of suppressed mixins cannot contain the applied mixin itself, but it can contain mixins which themselves suppress this mixin. Such circular suppressions result in both mixins being removed from the configuration.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.MixAttribute
member.summary: Configures that a class and a mixin should be mixed together.

remarks.para: This attribute is effective for the declarative mixin configuration, which is in effect by default when an application is started.

The is an alternative to and allowing assembly-level mixin configuration. Therefore, it is suitable for transparently putting mixins and classes together, with neither mixin nor target class explicitly referencing the other side of the relationship.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.BindToConstraintsAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a generic parameter of a mixin should be bound to a type inferred from the type parameter's generic constraints (unless the generic parameter type is explicitly specified when the mixin is configured).

remarks.para: Apply this attribute to a generic parameter of a generic mixin when the mixin engine should be able to automatically close the mixin type. Without the attribute, an exception will be thrown.

list.item: When there are no constraint or there is only a class constraint, the generic parameter is bound to .
When there is only a struct constraint, the generic parameter is bound to .
When there are multiple interface, type, struct, and class constraints that cannot be unified into a single type, an exception is thrown.

remarks.note: When a type parameter is reused for the generic parameter of the or base classes, the type parameter must satisfy several constraints. See and for more information.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.CompleteInterfaceAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an interface acts as a complete interface for a class instantiated via .

remarks.para: A complete interface combines the API of a target type with that of its mixins. For example, if a target class provides the methods A and B and a mixin adds the methods C and D, users of the class could normally only use either A and B or C and D at the same time (without casting). By implementing a complete interface that provides methods A, B, C, and D, users of the class can employ the full API in a simple way.
All methods specified by a complete interface must either be implemented on the target type or introduced via a mixin.

This interface can be applied multiple times if an interface is to be a complete interface for multiple target types. The attribute is not inherited, i.e. an interface inheriting from a complete interface does not automatically constitute a complete interface as well.

When the default mixin configuration is built via analysis of the declarative attributes, all complete interfaces are automatically registered with the active mixin configuration. This means that in the default mixin configuration, will be able to create instances from these interfaces.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.BindToGenericTargetParameterAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a generic parameter of a mixin should be bound to the mixin's target type's generic parameter (unless the generic parameter type is explicitly specified when the mixin is configured). Generic parameters with this attribute must be at the front of a mixin's generic parameter list, and they are mapped to the generic parameter of the target type by position.

remarks.note: When a type parameter is reused for the generic parameter of the or base classes, the type parameter must satisfy several constraints. See and for more information.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.AcceptsAlphabeticOrderingAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that an ordinal name comparison can be used to determine the order between two mixins when these override the same methods on a target object. Only use this if you don't care about the actual mixin order.

remarks.para: Ordering between mixins is important when two mixins override the same methods on a target object, because without a defined ordering, it wouldn't be deterministic which of the overrides would be executed first. Usually, orderings between mixins are expressed via dependencies. Either implicitly, because the mixin has a base call dependency (second type argument of the base class) to an interface implemented by another mixin, or explicitly via .

In some situations, however, a mixin cannot and does not need to specify a specific ordering simply because any override call order would be sufficient for its purpose. Such a mixin can opt into alphabetic ordering by having this attribute applied to it. Alphabetic ordering is only applied after all implicit or explicit dependencies have been analyzed. It is also ruled out if two or more of the mixins involved do not accept alphabetic ordering.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.OverrideMixinAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a target class member overrides a virtual or abstract member of one of the mixins combined with the class.

remarks.para: An overriding member and its base member must both be public or protected, and they must have the same name and signature. If an overriding member would apply to multiple mixin members, this is regarded as a configuration error, unless the mixin type is explicitly specified in this attribute's constructor.
This attribute is inherited (i.e. if the overriding member is replaced in a subclass, the subclass' member is now the overriding member) and can only be applied once per member.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.IFuncInvoker`1
member.summary: This interface allows invokers with fixed arguments to be returned without references to their generic argument types.

remarks.p: Note that casting a struct to an interface is a boxing operation, thus creating an object on the heap and garbage collecting it later. For very performance-critical scenarios, it be better to avoid this and accept the references to the invoker's generic argument types.

It is recommended to wrap this interface within a , because returning an interface could lead to ambigous castings if the final call to is missing, while using structs will usually lead to a compile-time error as expected.

member.name: F:Remotion.Mixins.MixinKind.Extending
member.summary: The mixin extends the target class from the outside, the target class might not know about being mixed. The mixin therefore has the possibility to override attributes (with set to false) and interfaces declared or implemented by the target class.

member.name: F:Remotion.Mixins.MixinKind.Used
member.summary: The mixin is explicitly used by the target class. The mixin therefore behaves more like a base class, eg. attributes (with set to false) and interfaces introduced by the mixin can be overridden by the target class.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.ObjectFactory
member.summary: Provides support for instantiating type which are combined with mixins.

remarks.para: When a target class ist combined with mixins, the target class cannot be instantiated by an ordinary constructor call. Instead, a mixed type has to be created first, and this type is then instantiated. The class provides a simple API to creating and instantiating mixed types. (To create a mixed type without instantiating it, use the class.)
The class uses the mixin configuration active on the current thread. Use the MixinConfiguration class if the configuration needs to be adapted.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.ObjectFactory.Create``1(Remotion.Reflection.ParamList,System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates a mixed instance of the given type with a public constructor.
member.typeparam: The target type a mixed instance of which should be created.
member.param: A object holding the parameters to be passed to the constructor.

The pre-instantiated mixin instances to integrate into the mixed instance. You can specify all, none, or a subset of the mixins currently configured with . Those mixins for which no prepared instances are given will be automatically created when the mixed object is constructed.
member.returns: A mixed instance of a type derived from .

exception.para: The current mixin configuration for the target type violates at least one validation rule, which makes it impossible to crate a mixed type.
The current mixin configuration for the target type contains severe configuration problems that make generation of a target class definition object impossible.
- or -
The constructor of the mixed object threw an exception.
The base type is an interface and it cannot be determined which class to instantiate.
-or-
The parameter contains at least one mixin instance which is not defined as a mixin for the target type in the current thread's mixin configuration.

remarks.para: This method internally uses with . This means that mixed types are only created for instances which do have an active mixin configuration. All other types passed to this method are directly instantiated, without code generation.
The method supports the creation of instances from their complete interfaces: can be an interface registered in the current mixin configuration. See also .

member.name: T:Remotion.AdapterRegistry
member.summary: Used to register instances.
member.remarks: Used by those modules of the framework that do not have binary depedencies to another module to access information from this module.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.ExtendsAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a mixin extends a specific class, providing some part of its functionality or public interface.

remarks.para: This attribute is effective for the declarative mixin configuration, which is in effect by default when an application is started.

Although the attribute itself is not inherited, its semantics in mixin configuration are: If a base class is configured to be mixed with a mixin type M by means of the , this configuration setting is inherited by each of its (direct and indirect) subclasses. The subclasses will therefore also be mixed with the same mixin type M unless a second mixin M2 derived from M is applied to the subclass, thus overriding the inherited configuration. If M is configured for both base class and subclass, the base class configuration is ignored.

This attribute can be applied to the same mixin class multiple times if it extends multiple target classes. It should not however be used to apply the same mixin multiple times to the same target class.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.ExtendsAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The target type extended by this mixin.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.ExtendsAttribute.TargetType
member.summary: Gets the target type the mixin class applies to.
member.value: The target type the mixin class applies to.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.ExtendsAttribute.MixinTypeArguments
member.summary: Gets or sets the generic type arguments to be used when applying a generic mixin to the given target type. This is useful when the is to be applied to a generic mixin class, but the default generic type specialization algorithm of the mixin engine does not give the desired results.
member.value: The generic type arguments to close the generic mixin type with.
member.remarks: If this attribute is applied to a non-generic mixin class or if the types supplied don't match the mixin's generic parameters, an exception is thrown when the mixin configuration is analyzed.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoresClassAttribute
member.summary: Defines that a mixin is not applied to a specific class, even when it is explicitly or implicitly configured for that class via the declarative configuration attributes , , and .

remarks.para: Use this attribute to exclude a target class inherited from a mixin's base class. This attribute is not inherited, so the target class exclusion will only work for the exact mixin to which the attribute is applied.

Note that when a mixin excludes a generic type definition (e.g. C<>), a corresponding closed generic type (C<int>) can still inherit the mixin from its base class. This is by design due to the rule that a closed generic type inherits mixins from both its base class and its generic type definition.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoresClassAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the class to be ignored by this mixin.
member.param: The class to be ignored in declarative configuration. Subclasses of this class will not inherit the mixin either.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoresClassAttribute.ClassToIgnore
member.summary: Gets the class to be ignored by this mixin.

member.name: T:Remotion.Reflection.IConstructorLookupInfo
member.summary: Represents an object that can be used to lookup and dynamically invoke constructors of a specific defining type.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin
member.summary: Provides reflective access to the mixins integrated with a target class.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin.Get``1(System.Object)
member.summary: Gets the instance of the specified mixin type that was mixed into the given .
member.typeparam: The mixin type to get an instance of.
member.param: The mixin target to get the mixin instance from.
member.returns: The instance of the specified mixin type that was mixed into the given mixin target, or if the target does not include a mixin of that type.
member.remarks: This method cannot be used with mixins that have been configured as open generic type definitions. Use the non-generic variant instead.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin.Get(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Gets the instance of the specified that was mixed into the given .
member.param: The mixin type to get an instance of.
The mixin target to get the mixin instance from.
member.returns: The instance of the specified mixin type that was mixed into the given mixin target, or if the target does not include a mixin of that type.
member.remarks: This method can also be used with mixins that have been configured as open generic type definitions. Use the open generic type definition to retrieve them, but be prepared to get an instance of a specialized (closed) generic type back.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin`2
member.summary: Base class for mixins that require a reference to their target object () and a reference for making base calls ().
member.typeparam: The minimum type required for calling methods on the target object ().
The minimum type required for making base calls () when overriding a method of the target class.

remarks.para: Typically, this base class will be used whenever a mixin overrides a method of a target class and it needs to call the overridden base implementation. Derive from the class if you only need the target object reference but are not making any base calls, or use any base class if not even the target object reference is required.
is called the face type requirement or This-dependency of the mixin, and can be assigned a class or interface (or a type parameter with class or interface constraints).

is also called the base call type requirement or Base-dependency of the mixin and can be assigned an interface or the type (or a type parameter with interface or constraints). The Base-dependencies of a mixin define the order in which method overrides are executed when multiple mixins override the same target method: when mixin A has a Base-dependency on an interface IB, its override will be executed before any mixin implementing the interface IB.

If a subclass of this class is also a generic type (with at most two generic type parameters, each of which is bound to one of this class' generic type parameters), it can be configured as a mixin in its open generic type definition form (typeof (C<,>)). In such a case, the mixin engine will try to close it at the time of configuration analysis; for this to succeed, the following rules must apply:

item.para: The type parameter bound to must have at most one type constraint. The mixin engine will try to assign the target type of the mixin to this parameter when analyzing the configuration, if allowed by the constraints. A mixin writer can use this for introducing interfaces as follows:
In this example, the mixin will introduce the interface for its target class T.

If the mixin engine cannot bind the type parameter to the target type (e.g. because the parameter has an incompatible type constaint), it will bind it to a type compatible with the parameter's constraint (or if no constraint exists) and the mixin implementer should not depend on this type parameter when introducing interfaces. If the constraint (if any) is not satisfied by the interfaces introduced via the mixins applied to the target type, the mixin configuration is invalid.

list.item: The type parameter bound to must have at most one type constraint. The mixin engine will assign a type compatible with this constraint (or if no constraint exists) to the parameter when analyzing the configuration, and the mixin implementer should not depend on this type parameter when introducing interfaces. If the constraint (if any) is not satisfied by the interfaces introduced via the mixins applied to the target type, the mixin configuration is invalid.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin`1
member.summary: Base class for mixins that require a reference to their target object ().
member.typeparam: The minimum type required for calling methods on the target object ().

remarks.para: Typically, this base class will be used for those mixins which do require a reference to their target object, but which do not overrride any methods. Derive from the class if you need to override target methods, or use any base class if not even the target object reference is required.
is called the face type requirement or This-dependency of the mixin, and can be assigned a class or interface (or a type parameter with class or interface constraints).

If a subclass of this class is also a generic type (with at most one generic type parameter, which is bound to the type parameter), it can be configured as a mixin in its open generic type definition form (typeof (C<>)). In such a case, the mixin engine will try to close it at the time of configuration analysis; for this to succeed, the following rule must apply:

item.para: The type parameter bound to must have at most one type constraint. The mixin engine will try to assign the target type of the mixin to this parameter when analyzing the configuration, if allowed by the constraints. A mixin writer can use this for introducing interfaces as follows:
In this example, the mixin will introduce the interface for its target class T.

If the mixin engine cannot bind the type parameter to the target type (e.g. because the parameter has an incompatible type constaint), it will bind it to a type compatible with the parameter's constraint (or if no constraint exists), and the mixin implementer should not depend on this type parameter when introducing interfaces. If the constraint (if any) is not satisfied by the interfaces introduced via the mixins applied to the target type, the mixin configuration is invalid.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin`1.OnInitialized
member.summary: Called when the mixin has been initialized and its properties can be safely accessed.

member.name: M:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin`1.OnDeserialized
member.summary: Called when the mixin has been deserialized and its properties can be safely accessed.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin`1.This
member.summary: Gets a reference to the concrete mixed object.
member.exception: The mixin has not been initialized yet, probably because the property is accessed from the mixin's constructor.
member.remarks:
This property must not be accessed from the mixin's constructor; if you need to initialize the mixin by accessing the property, override the method.
Be careful when calling members that this mixin overrides via the property, this can easily throw a because the property includes all mixins defined on the target object. Use instead to call the base implementations of overridden members.

member.name: P:Remotion.Mixins.Mixin`2.Base
member.summary: Gets an object reference for performing base calls from member overrides.
member.exception: The mixin has not been initialized yet, probably because the property is accessed from the mixin's constructor.

remarks.para: This property must not be accessed from the mixin's constructor; if you need to initialize the mixin by accessing the property, override the method.

This property is only for performing base calls from overridden methods. It should not be used to access arbitrary methods of the mixin's target object, use the property for instead. If the property is used other than to perform base calls from member overrides and more than one mixin is applied to the target object, unexpected behavior may arise because the property will represent the target object together with only a subset, but not all of its mixins.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.IgnoreForMixinConfigurationAttribute
member.summary: Causes the mixin engine to ignore all mixin configuration attributes on the type this attribute is applied to when building the default mixin configuration.

member.name: T:Remotion.Implementation.FrameworkVersionNotFoundException
member.summary: Thrown by when the framework version cannot be determined automatically. Use to manually set the version or add a reference to the framework implementation assembly.

member.name: T:Remotion.Implementation.FrameworkVersion
member.summary: Holds the object used by to retrieve types from the re-motion implementation assemblies.

member.name: M:Remotion.Implementation.FrameworkVersion.Reset
member.summary: Resets the version information so that the next retrieval of will trigger an automatic resolution. After calling this method, can be used to set a different value.

member.name: M:Remotion.Implementation.FrameworkVersion.RetrieveFromType(System.Type)
member.summary: Retrieves from version information from the assembly defining the given type. This is a shortcut for the following statemnt: Value = frameworkType.Assembly.GetName ().Version;
member.param: A framework type to retrieve the version from.

member.name: P:Remotion.Implementation.FrameworkVersion.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the framework version value.
member.value: The framework version value. If none has been set, the getter will attempt to retrieve the version automatically (and throw an exception if it cannot do so). When one version has been set, no other version can be set unless is called before. (The same version can be set without an exception being thrown.)

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.CopyCustomAttributesAttribute
member.summary: When applied to a mixin, specifies a class whose custom attributes should be added to the mixin's target class. This is useful when a mixin should add certain attributes without itself exposing those attributes.

member.name: T:Remotion.Mixins.GenerationPolicy
member.summary: Defines how the and behave when asked to generate a concrete type for a target type without any mixin configuration information.

member.name: F:Remotion.Mixins.GenerationPolicy.ForceGeneration
member.summary: Specifies that and should always generate concrete types, no matter whether mixin configuration information exists for the given target type or not.

member.name: F:Remotion.Mixins.GenerationPolicy.GenerateOnlyIfConfigured
member.summary: Specifies that and should only generate concrete types if mixin configuration information exists for the given target type.

member.name: T:Remotion.Implementation.VersionDependentImplementationBridge`1
member.summary: Provides a bridge between a version-independent interface and a version-dependent implementation of that interface by querying for a in the interface and instantiating the type mentioned by that interface using .
member.typeparam: The interface type to be resolved with a version-dependent implementation.
